_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Hazard Assessment
The Hazard Assessment is comprised of a Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenario each for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide systems, as well as a 5-Year Accident History for the same. The Hazard Assessment was conducted as an initial screening procedure as part of determining into which Program Level (1, 2, or 3) the Burton Creek WWTP. Public receptors are located within the EPA-defined endpoint concentrations of Burton Creek's Worst-Case releases. Therefore, the plant is ineligible for Program 1 and because Texas public utilities are currently excluded from Program 3, Burton Creek is understood to be a RMP Program 2 facility.  

Worst Case Scenarios
The Worst Case Scenarios were defined as a ton cylinder (2,000 pounds) of chlorine or sulfur dioxide, each being released by a catastrophic event within 10-minute duration. These scenarios were developed and modeled using the EPA RMP*Comp. The toxic endpoints for both chlorine (0.0087 mg/L) and sulfur dioxide (0.0078 mg/L) were determined to be 1.30 miles.

Alternative Release Scenarios
The Alternative Releases Scenarios of chlorine and sulfur dioxide were also modeled using RMP*Comp. Source term estimations of approximately 175 pounds of either chlorine or sulfur dioxide gas released were derived from a scenario of a flexible connection failure. The dispersion model estimated chlorine (0.0087 mg/L) and sulfur dioxide (0.0078 mg/L) endpoints to extend 0.10 miles.

5-Year Accident History
No accidents have occurred at the plant involving either onsite or offsite consequences. 

Document Management System
A Document Management System was established to attribute responsibility for the development, implementation, and maintenance of the Risk Management Program. The Program must be updated every three years, or any time a covered process undergoes a physical or administrative modification.  The Document Management System is largely a function of the Risk Management Program Team, described below.

Risk Man

agement Program Team
The following members are responsible for the Risk Management Program development, implementation, and maintenance. The Public Works Director has the ultimate responsibility.

Prevention Program
This section is comprised of Safety Information, Hazard Review, Operating Procedures, Training, Maintenance, Incident Investigation, and 	Compliance Audit procedures.  Each has an entire chapter devoted to it in this RMP, and is described in more detail below.

Safety Information
Safety Information is divided between Chemical Safety Information, and Process Safety Information.  Each is described below:

Chemical Safety Information
Comprehensive chemical data is provided in this section to include regulatory reporting and action thresholds, health hazard and chemical exposure limitations, as well as detailed physical properties of each regulated substance. This information was compiled from numerous sources, and is intended to be a one-stop source for the reader seeking data on these substances. The physical data will provide useful information in the inevitable event the plant processes are modified, thereby requiring revisited dense gas dispersion modeling.

Process Safety Information
Process Safety Information was meticulously compiled on each system studied. Specifications on each process are collocated in one place for easy reference. Details such as Maximum Intended Inventory, Safe Upper and Lower Temperatures, Safe Upper and Lower Pressures, and Codes and Standards Used to Design, Build and Operate the Process are provided in this section. 

*NOTE* Site is manned 10 hours per day, 7 days a week. Afterhours monitoring and control is accomplished through SCADA.

Hazard Review
A Hazard Review was conducted for each regulated process. The team consisted of plant management and operations personnel knowledgeable in use of the plants gas systems and the Hazard Review process. The Hazard Review technique used was a hybrid Hazard and Operability Study (HA

ZOP), in the form of a "what if" analysis. The result of the Hazard Review is a set of recommendations for the Plant to implement. The Rule under 40 CFR 68.50 requires the City of Bryan to ensure that problems identified are "resolved in a timely manner."  For those items that can not be promptly resolved, it is recommended that a schedule be developed that addresses those issues, with personnel responsibility assigned for each.  

Operating Procedures
Operating Procedures have been developed for the Burton Creek WWTP. They provide system descriptions, specifications, and operating procedures for the chlorine and sulfur dioxide gas systems. Procedures include Start, Shutdown, Normal, Abnormal, and Emergency Operation. Also included are Troubleshooting Procedures.

Training 
Training is required by EPA to be included in the Risk Management Program. A program has been developed with guidelines on how to conduct regular and structured plant training. Training record forms are included with the Program for the required training documentation. Additionally, a training record has been compiled and included for all affected personnel associated with the covered processes.

Maintenance
A Maintenance Program has been developed with associated documentation forms. Sound preventive maintenance will reduce potential hazards to personnel onsite, and to the off-site public. State and federal regulators will most surely expect to see documentation and recordkeeping associated with the Maintenance Program. 

Incident Investigation
An Incident Investigation Program has been developed. The EPA has established strict guidelines to follow in the aftermath of any release involving either the chlorine or sulfur dioxide system. The Incident Investigation Program outlines key milestones that must be accomplished as soon as possible, but not later than 48-hours following the incident. Ultimately, it is desired that the plant learn from the incident and take action to prevent similar inciden

ts in the future. Incident Investigation Report Forms are included, and must be maintained for a minimum of five years after each incident.

Compliance Audits
Internal Compliance Audits must be conducted every three years to verify compliance with the programs and procedures contained in this document. The Public Works Director must certify that the Risk Management Program team has evaluated compliance with the provisions of the Program, and verify that the procedures and practices are adequate and are being followed. Audit Report Forms are provided, the two most recent of which must always be maintained. 

Emergency Response Program
The Emergency Response Program is included as part of the Risk Management Program, in case a significant release ever occurs. As in all the above programs, it is important to review this program regularly. The RMP Rule, 40 CFR 68.95 requires training for all employees "in relevant procedures" of the Emergency Response Program.

Open Records Requests
A copy of the Risk Management Plan is provided under the RMP E*Submit tab. This document is public information and has been uploaded on an EPA, public-access database. No other portion of the Burton Creek WWTP Risk Management Program must be made available to the public [Clean Air Act Section 112(r). Exempt: classified or confidential business information or the off-site consequences analysis information]. 

Members of the public desiring access to the RMP may do so by:
* Visiting the designated federal reading room.
* Contacting their State Emergency Reponses Commission or Local Emergency Planning 
   Committee public contact to arrange an appropriate means of viewing.
* Submitting a Freedom of Information Act request to obtain non-offsite consequence analysis RMP data. 

Summary of Action Items for the City of Bryan
The RMP Rule, 40 CFR 68.42 requires that details of all accidental releases be recorded from this date forward.  The format details are provided in Chapter 3.

The RMP Rule, 40

CFR 68.15 requires that the Document Management System (e.g., the RMP Team) be updated anytime personnel changes or administrative changes are made that would affect the lines of authority or responsibility for maintaining the RMP at the Burton Creek WWTP. The format details are provided in Chapter 4.

The RMP Rule, 40 CFR 68.54 requires that each employee presently operating a process, and each employee newly assigned to a covered process be trained or tested competent in the operating procedures.  Training documentation forms are provided in Chapter 9.

The RMP Rule, 40 CFR 68.56 requires training on the plant maintenance procedures provided in Chapter 10.  The City of Bryan must train or cause to be trained each employee involved in maintaining the on-going mechanical integrity of the process.  To ensure that the employee can perform the job tasks in a safe manner, each such employee must be trained in the hazards of the process, in how to avoid or correct unsafe conditions, and in the procedures applicable to the employee's job tasks. Training documentation forms are provided in Chapter 9.

All maintenance contractors must ensure that each contract maintenance employee is trained to perform any applicable maintenance procedures (provided in each RMP document). Training documentation forms are provided in Chapter 9.

Refresher training on operating and maintenance procedures must be provided every three years. Training documentation forms are provided in Chapter 9.

The RMP Rule, 40 CFR 68.60 requires incident investigations not later than 48-hours following each incident. That guidance is provided in Chapter 11.

The RMP Rule, 40 CFR 68.58 requires the City of Bryan to certify compliance with RMP Accident Prevention Program provisions at least every three years to verify that the procedures and practices developed under the rule are adequate and are being followed.  That guidance, along with Compliance Audit forms, is provided in Chapter 12.

The RMP Rule, 40 C

FR 68.95 requires training for all employees "in relevant procedures" of the Emergency Response Program.  It is recommended that training on the specific plant procedures take place upon initial employment and every three years thereafter. Other training recommendations are discussed in the Emergency Response Program as appropriate to the level of response. The Emergency Response Program is discussed in Chapter 13. Training documentation forms are provided in Chapter 9.
